Que Minecraft Dungeons sea gratis en Xbox Cloud Gaming en m√≥vil y que tenga skins personalizados.

‚ú® Ojal√° Mojang pueda considerar pronto esta idea. Ser√≠a incre√≠ble jugar Minecraft Dungeons gratis en Xbox Cloud Gaming y usar nuestras propias skins personalizadas en m√≥vil. Muchos jugadores lo esperamos con emoci√≥n. üíö

üí° Esta propuesta ser√≠a una gran mejora para todos los jugadores. Minecraft Dungeons en Xbox Cloud Gaming con la opci√≥n de usar skins personalizadas en m√≥vil har√≠a la experiencia m√°s divertida y accesible para todos. Ojal√° Mojang la tome en cuenta pronto. ‚öîÔ∏è
Propongo que Minecraft Dungeons en Xbox Cloud Gaming permita importar skins personalizadas desde el m√≥vil, para que los jugadores puedan personalizar sus personajes con sus dise√±os favoritos.‚Äù
Ser√≠a genial agregar un modo cooperativo en l√≠nea para m√≥viles con amigos, permitiendo que m√°s jugadores disfruten de Minecraft Dungeons juntos y aumente la diversi√≥n en comunidad.‚Äù

Sugiero un sistema de creaci√≥n de skins din√°micas basado en colores y texturas personalizables dentro del juego, como un peque√±o editor integrado en Minecraft Dungeons para personalizar personajes f√°cilmente.‚Äù
Propongo agregar un mapa tem√°tico inspirado en las monta√±as de Veracruz, con enemigos y misiones ambientadas en la regi√≥n, para explorar y conocer la cultura mexicana mientras se juega.‚Äù

Sugiero crear un mapa de un templo azteca dentro de Minecraft Dungeons, con trampas, acertijos y tesoros escondidos, para que los jugadores puedan experimentar aventuras basadas en la historia y arquitectura de los antiguos aztecas.‚Äù

Propongo agregar misiones de exploraci√≥n en niveles especiales donde los jugadores busquen tesoros escondidos y desbloqueen secretos, incluyendo mapas con tem√°tica de templos antiguos y arquitectura hist√≥rica.‚Äù

Sugiero que Minecraft Dungeons en Xbox Cloud Gaming permita importar skins personalizadas directamente desde la galer√≠a del dispositivo, tal como se hace en Minecraft Bedrock, para que los jugadores puedan usar sus dise√±os favoritos f√°cilmente en el juego.‚Äù

Propongo crear un mapa ambientado en la regi√≥n de Orizaba en la √©poca de los aztecas, espec√≠ficamente en Ahuilizapan. Este mapa podr√≠a incluir la ciudad de Nahuani y la leyenda del volc√°n Pico de Orizaba, con enemigos, acertijos y tesoros, para que los jugadores vivan aventuras hist√≥ricas y culturales en Minecraft Dungeons.‚Äù

Hola, propongo que en Minecraft Dungeons se agreguen mapas de iglesias importantes de M√©xico, incluyendo: Bas√≠lica de la Virgen de Guadalupe, Iglesia de la Virgen de Juquila, Iglesia del Santo Cristo Rey, Catedral de Xalapa (tumba de San Rafael Guzal), Iglesia del Santo Ni√±o Doctor de Tepeaca, Iglesia de la Virgen de San Juan de los Lagos, Iglesia de Zapopan y Los Remedios, Iglesias de los 3 Ni√±os M√°rtires de Tlaxcala. Esto permitir√≠a explorar lugares hist√≥ricos sin involucrar figuras religiosas directamente.

Sugiero que se agreguen mapas de monta√±as y volcanes de M√©xico, incluyendo: Cerro del Borrego (Orizaba), Volc√°n Pico de Orizaba, Cerro del Tepeyac. Estos mapas permitir√≠an a los jugadores explorar la geograf√≠a natural de M√©xico y conocer su riqueza cultural y geogr√°fica dentro de Minecraft Dungeons.

Ser√≠a genial que los mapas incluyan tanto iglesias como monta√±as importantes de M√©xico, para que los jugadores puedan explorar la geograf√≠a y edificaciones hist√≥ricas juntas: Bas√≠lica de Guadalupe, Cerro del Tepeyac, Catedral de Xalapa, Pico de Orizaba, entre otros. Esto enriquecer√≠a la experiencia de Minecraft Dungeons con elementos culturales y naturales.

> ‚ÄúHola, Mojang üëã
Quiero reforzar mi sugerencia sobre Minecraft Dungeons: que sea gratis en Xbox Cloud Gaming y que permita usar skins personalizadas en m√≥vil.

Esto ayudar√≠a a que Dungeons vuelva a ser un juego activo en todas las plataformas, con actualizaciones, correcciones y nuevas funciones, como sucede con Minecraft Bedrock.

Mi propuesta sigue siendo justa y beneficiosa para todos los jugadores de Minecraft Dungeons üíö‚öîÔ∏è.

Gracias por considerar mi sugerencia üëç‚Äù

> Hola Mojang.
S√© que Minecraft Dungeons ya no recibir√° m√°s contenido nuevo ni actualizaciones desde la versi√≥n 1.17, y respeto completamente esa decisi√≥n.

Esta sugerencia no pide desarrollo nuevo, solo dos cosas que s√≠ son posibles sin actualizar el juego:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Que Minecraft Dungeons est√© disponible gratis en Xbox Cloud Gaming para m√≥vil.
Esto no necesita una actualizaci√≥n del juego, solo un cambio de licencia en Xbox Cloud.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Que se permita usar skins personalizadas en la versi√≥n m√≥vil de Xbox Cloud Gaming.
Esto depende del sistema de Xbox Cloud, no del c√≥digo del juego.

Con estos dos cambios, m√°s jugadores podr√≠an disfrutar Minecraft Dungeons sin pedir contenido nuevo.
Gracias por leer mi propuesta.

So people are talking about /locate variants and:

 

/locate biome <biome>

returns the center coordinate of the biome.

ex. /locate biome mushroom_fields returns 62362 ~ -13764

 

/locate structure <structure>

works as /locate does currently

ex. /locate structure Village returns 102 ~ -944

 

/locate player <username>

returns an error (player not found) or coordinates of the player accompanied with the biome.

ex. /locate player RandomPlayer returns 0 65 0 in Nether

 

/locate entity <entity>

returns an error (no entities found) or coordinates of the nearest entity that fits the selector. You can also use UUIDs in the command. You must limit your @e selector to 1.

ex. /locate entity @e[type=horse,limit=1] returns Horse at -80 ~ 67

 

/locate block <type of block>

returns the coordinates of the nearest block specified.

ex. /locate block diamond_ore returns -65, 11, 13

 

Also, I think /locate structure should follow a more file-oriented format, like this: /locate structure minecraft:village instead of this: /locate structure Village

Idea for full syntax:

/locate {Who/Where Syntax (@s, 100, 64, -350)} structure/biome/player {minecraft: list of 
things}

The Who/Where Syntax allows you to find the nearest _ where you are, but also the nearest one to a specific coord.

This could be used with command blocks as well, as well as, at the end, an optional, tp {Who Syntax} at the end, which will tp the selected players to the found area.

This would have to be alligned with chunks rather than blocks, because biomes are stored per chunk in the world files.

So it could be:

/setbiome ~ ~ ~ <biome> [variant]

where ~ ~ ~ can be any block inside the chunk that you want to change, and the set biome would be a random variant unless the variant parameter is specified.

This could also be with some additional tweaks to make it easier to set a large area for one biome type:

/setbiome from <x1> <y1> <z1> to <x2> <y2> <z2> <biome> [variant]

and

/setbiome at <x> <y> <z> <biome> [variant]

The "from to" command will fill an area with the specified biome type (and randomise different variants if the variant is not specified) and the "at" command will set the specified biome type for the chunk the specified co√∂rdinates are in.

 

For people worrying that the /setbiome ~ ~ ~ <biome> command that Luca Searle suggests will only 'setblock' for a biome:

- this is impossible, any kind of /setbiome command will always be per chunk and not per block.

The mechanics could go in at least 2 different directions:

/setbiome <center coordinates> <radius> <biome>

or

/setbiome <coords of one corner> <coords of the opposite corner> <biome>

 

or both could be merge into one like this:

/setbiome cylinder <center coordinates> <radius> <biome>

/setbiome cuboid <1st coordinates> <2nd coordinates> <biome>

Cylinder and cuboid mean that you shouldn't specify y coordinates, just x and z, because the biome extends to world height and down to void.
Yeah, I also think this is a great idea for map makers and you don't need to use programs and tools out there like: WorldEdit, MCEdit, WorldPainter, BiomePainter etc.

I have an idea:
/biome command
/biome locate [biome] locates a biome
/biome set [biome] sets the chunk you're in to a biome

Key:        # = number        [ ] = optional        < > = replace        x #    y #    z # = coordinates

Posable syntax:

 

/biome whole [x z] <Biome Name> [<Biome Variant>] [Fill]

(Sets the whole biome at the specified coordinates to another biome, not just 1 block)

 

/biome chunk [x z] <Biome Name> [<Biome Variant>] [Fill]

(Sets the chunk's biome at the specified coordinates to another biome)

 

/biome fill x1 z1 x2 z2 <Biome Name> [<Biome Variant>] [Fill]

(Sets the area's biome to another biome)

[x z]:

The coordinates of a column of blocks somewhere in the biome/chunk that is going to get changed.  If excluded, it is the x z coordinates of the command's execution.

 

<Biome Name>:

The name of the biome that the biome/chunk/area is going to get changed into.

 

[Fill]:

If you type "fill", the command re-generates the biome (this might make it above or below ground level)

[<Biome Variant>]:

One of these options: (leave out for random)

has [<list>]

(the biome must have these variants, but can have more.  Always has the base biome)

!has [<list>]

(The biome can't have these variants.  Has the base biome unless it was in the list.)

only [<list>]

Speculation: This means that we will probably have more than one biome at one y-coordinate. So each postion in a Minecraft world will have a data tag which dertermines the biome.

 

So the new command should be like this:

/setbiome <from:x,y,z> <to:x,y,z> [biome]

Example: /setbiome 0 0 0 100 256 100 minecraft:plains > The area of 100x256x100 blocks will be filled with the plains biome.

This would be better as an expansion on the /place command, along with a radius parameter so that micro-biomes can also be instantiated.

Format: /place biome [biome ID] [x] [y] [z]

 

Example: /place biome dark_forest ~ ~ ~

This command entry would force a Dark Forest biome to appear at the player's current coordinates.

 

Maybe there could be minimum and maximum radius parameters implemented.

 

Alt Format 1: /place biome [biome ID] [x] [y] [z] [maximum radius]

 

Alt Format 2: /place biome [biome ID] [x] [y] [z] [minimum radius] [maximum radius]

 

If only three numbers are given, they will be read as X Y Z coordinates.

If four numbers are given, they'll be read as X/Y/Z and a maximum radius.

If five numbers are given, they'll be read as X/Y/Z and minimum and maximum radii.

A command like this already exists?

Use /data get entity @p Inventory

Command format:

  • /see <target:target> inv // Shows the player's inventory - Original
  • /see <target:target> am // Shows the player's armor, offhand, and armor - I added
  • /see <target:target> ec // Shows the player's Ender Chest - I added
  • /see <target:target> stt // Shows the player's Health, Hunger, Armor Level, and Air Level - A Grass Block appears next to the Air level if the player is on land, and a Water Block if the player is in the water. (Lava block if lava)

Interface permissions:

  • Read
  • Add Items
  • Remove items added in this instance

Command permissions (Bedrock):

  • Open Containers (Required)

Command permissions (Win7, Mac, and Linux):

/replaceitem entity [entity] inventory.0

  could be replaced with

/inventory replace entity [entity] inventory.0

  and this could be

/inventory open canmodify entity [entity] inventory

/inventory open nomodify entity [entity] inventory

/inventory open giveonly entity [entity] inventory

/inventory open takeonly entity [entity] inventory

  It would also work with blocks and non-player entities

As MukiTanuki said, you can get any player's entire inventory using:

/data get entity @p Inventory

To get the name of an item in a player's inventory, you can use the index of the inventory (starting from zero), followed by a dot operator and the name of the NBT property (what I mean by NBT property will make sense if you use the command I gave above to look at your inventory), like this:

/data get entity @p Inventory[0].id

(Where Inventory is an NBT property, 0 is the first item in the inventory array, and id is an NBT property within the item object in the inventory array)

If you want to find if a player has an item, you can use the /execute command and test for player NBT:

/execute if entity @p[nbt = {Inventory: [{id: "minecraft:iron_sword"}]}] run say Hi

(Says hi only if the player has the selected item somewhere in their inventory)

To give a player an item, you can use the /give command. To remove an item from a player, you can use the /clear command.

/give @p minecraft:stone_sword 1

/clear @p minecraft:stone_sword 1

@PoolloverNathan If /data only works on the Java Edition (I don't know, I don't use PE or Bedrock), really this should be a request to bring /data to the other versions in my opinion, rather than adding a new command.

In reply to original poster's comment:

Base Command: /player (target) [arguments]
Examples:
/player Etanarvazac inv edit false
/player Etanarvazac stats
/player Etanarvazac perm advanced true

AreaInfo Arguments:
inv (viewType) [shulk:boolean] - See selected player's inventory, equipped armour, and offhand. Include Shulker would mean "inv true". Not specified would be false. You must also set a view type: view or edit.
stats - View player's basic stats: Health, Hunger, Armour, Air, Insomnia, Location (e.g: dim, x, y, z)
ec - Ended Chest inventory
eff - View current potion/beacon effects on the player.
perm (level) [boolean] - Allow player to use "/player" cmd, must be OP to use. Arguments: basic, advanced, opped

Permission Levels:
Basic - Stats, Effects
Advanced - Stats, Effects, Inventory (excl. Shulker, viewing only)
Opped - Stats, Effects, Inventory (incl. Shulker, and inv edits), Ended Chest, Permissions

I would really like this to be added, as I'm a server owner. It'd probably be better if it were shortened to /inventory and could also access mob loot tables and inventories. I would also like to suggest some other additions to this command. 

/inventory see [target] - Allows you to see the inventory, loot table, and/or armor of a target. Items with NBT data (shulker boxes, signs, chests, etc.) would show the NBT data.

/inventory chest [target] - Allows you to see the ender chest contents of a target. Only works on players.

/inventory copy [target] [item/s] - Allows you to overwrite your inventory with specific data from the target. If used on a mob with a loot table, the items from the loot table will be considered the target data. If used multiple times without disabling, the previously selected items to sync will be replaced with the new selection.

/inventory sync [target] [item/s] - Allows you to indefinitely share specific armor and items with a target. If used multiple times without disabling, the previous item/s to sync will be replaced with the new item/s.

/inventory sync off - Disables inventory/armor sharing.

/inventory clear [target] [item/s] - Replaces /clear.

/inventory give [target] [item/s] - Replaces /give.

Depending on Mojang's desires, taking items from an inventory could be part of /inventory see or another command entirely. More changes could allow ender chest syncing and copying. I hope these new additions will improve the idea of a see inventory command.

I was thinking something like

/inventorydisplay block <pos: vector3> <player> [bool: allowModification?]

to display a chest inventory, etc to <player>.

and

/inventorydisplay player <player1> <player2>

to display <player1>'s inventory to <player2> [bool: allowModification?]

 

allowModification would specify whether <player1> can add/remove items from the specified inventory.
